In an effort to revive waning school
spirit, the Pep committee has announced a rally and parade to precede the game with Lehigh.
The rally will be held at 11:20 on
Thursday, November 3 in room 120
of Latrobe hall. The whole football
team, together with several members
of previous teams, will be present.
Cheering Will be under the direction
of the cheerleaders, and music for
singing will be furnished by the
band.
On Saturday, November 5, a parade will be held in the vicinity of
the campus. The band, of course, will
lead the procession and the ROTC
will bring up the rear. Students who
participate in the parade will be rewarded with choice seats in the
cheering section.

The phrase representative self-government" can
only have one commonsense meaning. That meaning, certainly does not embrace a state of affairs in
which the Student council is
forced to appeal to the administration for assistance
when its independent decisions are questioned by the
campus as a whole; a state of affairs, to put it baldly,
in which student representatives are responsible, not
to their electorate, but to an impotent higher authority.
We're not particularly concerned at this moment
with the Original source of the Cotillion board purge.
We have, in fact, every reason to believe that it was
initiated by the Council. But, in the long run, the Board,
like all of us, rises and falls at the will of the administration. If you had desired it, the Board would have
remained on the campus. But, once condemned by you,
it could not be saved by all the pleas of the stud04
body.
Such a system of student government is by no stretch
of the imagination free and representative. Its undergraduate agencies are of necessity loaded up with
stooges with no claim •on the respect of honest men.
It is a snare and a delusion, a hollow mockery of the
democratic process.
You must have grown just as weary as the rest of
us at our ceaseless advocacy of various measures to
"liberalize" the Student council. We have petitioned,
if you remeniber, for the freest possible open discussion of matters before the Council. To a lesser extent
we have entreated candidates to take public positions
on such matters. Now, at last, we see the Council for
what it is. We will petition no further.
Any society of free men rests on the two fundamentals of representative self-government and unfettered discussions of conflicting ideas. To speak plainly,
our faith in the existence of the latter principle around
here has not survived the repression of the Young Communist league last winter. And now we have seen even
the myth of student government pass away.
We are fully conscious of the anomaly of our own
position. The NEWS-LETTER has always taken full advantage of its privilege of criticizing persons of importance whenever such criticism seemed called for. This
may be the last go-round. We are in no mood for future
compromise. In short, we can retreat no further.
It is difficult to be philosophical, when you see your
whole concept of justice ripped to pieces. It is difficult
to be temperate in the face of what you consider needless wrongs.
We have grown a bit too fond of the principles of
democracy and freedom to let them down now. The
time is yet at hand when the student body will exercise in full measure its rights of self-government.
And, for these rights, we have only just begun to fight.
Very truly yours,
MURRAY KEMPTON,
WETHERED BARROLL jr.

The Barnstormers, dramatic club
of the Johns Hopkins university, has
definitely chosen the comedy farce,
"She Loves Me Not" for their major
production this year.
John Desch, dramatics director for
"Once in a Lifetime," the 1936-37
Barnstormer show, has been secured
for the job of dramatics counselor for
the present production.
Mr Desch, the director, a teacher
of English at Baltimore City college,
and reputed to be one of the most successful directors in Baltimore, has had
experience with the production of
"She Loves Me Not" with other
troupes, and has worked with the Hopkins dramatic club in the past.
December 17 dates the University
performance of the play. The Auditorium theatre, one of the largest theatres in Baltimore, used in past years
for University plays, may be contracted again for this season. Previous plays never ran more than one
performance; discussion, however, on
the likelihood of continuing a successful play for three or more, has left
the issue open at present.
R McShane, president of the Barnstormers club; Robert Anderson, business manager; Sam Greenstein, production manager; Robert Feldman,
assistant; Tom Powers, and Alfred
Agrin are outstanding members of the
club who will begin work this week.
Victor Victoroff was chosen publicity
director in a meeting held Thursday,
October 27.
A "come one, come all" rally will be
held Tuesday at 4 pm to introduce the
new plans of the organization to the
student body, to announce changes in
policy, and to invite student actors for
tryouts for the play.
The farcial play has been most successful for the past four years, and
the policy of producing light comedy
will be continued, it was announced.
Try-outs for parts will be given beginning Tuesday, November 1 at the
Barn. Officers of the club, the director, and actors in previous Barnstormers shows will be on hand to coach.
Scene-designers, property men, electricians, and others interested in the
stage from the production end will be _
invited at the rally to contribute their
time and effort to the 'Stormers.
At an unofficial meeting on October
12, twenty-five men registered for
work on the season's cast.

it was pointed out, and opportunity

Dr Lindeman built his talk around
the theme that "the need of our
time, this transitional age, is the application of science and technology
to the fulfillment of human needs in
their widest sense. Science provides
the needs; the ideals and patterns
which are to guide and give value to
this social action are religion."
Describing our age as one of transition which as such has peculiar dangers, Dr Lindeman thought the outcome of these dangers, was the likelihood of groups and individuals seeking various escapes instead of facing the difficulties of the social problems which arise at such times.

Dr Lindeman discussed and analyzed the mutual relationship of the
concepts of science and religion and
their bearing upon the concepts of
democracy and social needs, saying
that religion provides the ideals and
motivation of social action, whereas
science provides the instrumentality.

A record concert is to be presented

and Night school and serves as a
gathering force for those who are interested in music, whether or not

have ever studied music. However,
those who play instruments or sing
are urged to join. Several concerts
will be presented by the group during
the year.

Bach: Chorales: Jesu, Joy of my Desiring.
Vater unser, Herzlich tut.

Debussy: Clair de Lune.
